quiz.title: Unit 3: Demand and Supply (Quiz 7)
quiz.subtitle: 3.7 Determinants of Supply: Factors Shifting Supply Curves (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Supply Shifters, Non-Price Determinants, Changes in Supply vs Quantity Supplied

questions.question: Which of the following would cause the entire supply curve for cars to shift to the right?
options: A decrease in the price of cars
An increase in the price of cars
questions.explanation: Improved technology reduces production costs, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right. Changes in the good's own price cause movement along the curve.

questions.question: If the cost of steel increases for automobile manufacturers, the supply curve for cars will:
options: Cause movement along the supply curve
questions.explanation: Higher input costs make production more expensive, reducing the quantity producers are willing to supply at each price, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: Which factor is NOT a determinant of supply that would shift the supply curve?
questions.explanation: The good's own price causes movement along the supply curve. The other factors are supply shifters that move the entire curve.

questions.question: If the government provides subsidies to solar panel manufacturers, the supply curve for solar panels will:
options: Cause movement along the supply curve
questions.explanation: Subsidies effectively lower production costs, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: If producers expect the price of their product to increase significantly next month, current supply will:
questions.explanation: Expectations of future price increases encourage producers to reduce current supply and wait to sell when prices are higher, shifting the current supply curve to the left.

questions.question: If new firms enter the smartphone market, the market supply curve for smartphones will:
questions.explanation: More producers means more production capacity at each price level, increasing overall market supply and shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: Which scenario would cause the supply curve for agricultural products to shift to the left?
questions.explanation: A drought reduces agricultural output, decreasing the quantity producers can supply at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: If taxes on production increase, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Taxes increase production costs, reducing the quantity producers are willing to supply at each price, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: The difference between a 'change in supply' and a 'change in quantity supplied' is that:
options: A change in supply involves movement along the curve, while a change in quantity supplied shifts the curve
A change in supply shifts the curve, while a change in quantity supplied involves movement along the curve
Both terms mean the same thing
Only quantity supplied can change, supply is always fixed
questions.explanation: A change in supply refers to a shift of the entire supply curve due to non-price factors. A change in quantity supplied refers to movement along the curve due to price changes.

questions.question: If the price of natural gas decreases and natural gas is used in manufacturing, the supply curve for manufactured goods will:
questions.explanation: Lower energy costs reduce production expenses, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: For producers of both wheat and corn, if the price of corn increases significantly, the supply curve for wheat will likely:
questions.explanation: Farmers may switch from wheat to corn production when corn prices rise, reducing wheat supply and shifting the wheat supply curve to the left.

questions.question: If government regulations become more stringent and increase compliance costs, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Increased regulatory costs raise production expenses, reducing the quantity producers are willing to supply at each price, shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: The main determinants of supply that shift the supply curve include all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: The good's own price causes movement along the supply curve. Input prices, technology, prices of related goods, expectations, number of sellers, and government policies are supply shifters.

questions.question: If a major factory closes down, reducing the number of producers in a market, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Fewer producers means less total production capacity at each price level, decreasing overall market supply and shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: If producers develop a more efficient production process that reduces waste, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Increased efficiency lowers production costs, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: During a labor strike that disrupts production, the supply curve for the affected goods will:
questions.explanation: Production disruptions reduce output, decreasing the quantity available at each price level and shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: If the government removes a production tax, the supply curve will:
questions.explanation: Removing taxes lowers production costs, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

questions.question: The six main determinants of supply that shift the supply curve are:
options: Price, income, technology, taxes, subsidies, weather
Input prices, technology, expectations, number of sellers, prices of related goods, government policies
Costs, demand, number of buyers, seasons, trends, regulations
Weather, technology, consumer tastes, income, taxes, subsidies
questions.explanation: The six main supply shifters are: prices of inputs, technology, producer expectations, number of sellers, prices of related goods in production, and government policies (taxes, subsidies, regulations).

questions.question: If a hurricane damages oil refineries, the supply curve for gasoline will:
questions.explanation: Damage to production facilities reduces output capacity, decreasing the quantity available at each price level and shifting the supply curve to the left.

questions.question: If automation reduces labor costs in manufacturing, the supply curve for manufactured goods will:
questions.explanation: Lower labor costs reduce production expenses, making producers willing to supply more at each price level, shifting the supply curve to the right.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand the determinants of supply and can accurately predict how various factors shift supply curves.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic supply shifters but review the specific effects of input prices, technology changes, and producer expectations.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on the six main supply shifters: input prices, technology, expectations, number of sellers, prices of related goods, and government policies. Remember that the good's own price causes movement along the curve.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember the key difference: changes in the good's own price cause movement along the supply curve, while changes in other factors shift the entire supply curve.
